they're not participants know what stand
down is
people know in San Diego that this is
going to happen every year they tell
their friends on the street they talk to

go to stand down for 20 years veteran's
village of San Diego has organized stand
down it is the oldest and best-known
program for homeless veterans over a
July weekend this empty field near San
Diego Airport will host an array of free
housing and social services to help
homeless vets get back on their feet and
let them know they are not forgotten
they're anxious to get in they know that
if they can get through the gate
save their lives tomorrow this is gonna
transform into something beautiful I am
so appreciative that you're all here and
it's not even eight o'clock stand down
is a military term that describes when
soldiers were given a break from the
front lines the difficult conversations
will come later but first the new
participants take care of some basic
needs a bed a shower a haircut and some
new clothes a few already know the drill
I'm gonna go eat and then I'm taking a
nap organizers say their main goal is to
create a supportive environment where
veterans can start rebuilding their
lives we bring them back to their youth
we're bringing back to a time when they
felt strong because what we're looking
to do is not just give people stuff but
to make them feel hopeful at stand down
each participant is assigned to a tent
in each tent is staffed with volunteer
tent leaders who counseled the vets and
help them access services I'm not
working right now I laid off David Cote
a Marine Corps captain is a tent leader
for Bravo the best way that I've found
to interact well with the members of my
tent is to say what is it that you want
to get out stand down today and I
usually start with something easy like
medical do your teeth hurt you want to
go see the dentist or get a new set of
glasses then the tougher questions and
nobody wants to always give the truth
right away do you need job counseling
and do you need housing so those will
come later I try to build a rapport kind
of that mentoring role kind of the Big
Brother coaching role they're
comfortable with that they see that they
see that you care more than one out of
every four homeless are veterans many
stand down participants became homeless
through some combination of disability
substance abuse and mental health
problems but now because of economic
issues a new crop of veterans has
started to come to stand down I just
became homeless about two weeks ago I
lost
time ago and could not find another one
and the rain came due could not pay the
rent so I live between my car sleeping
my car and sleeping in a flophouse like
came here and into the bench of the
services here like I got my hair guy got
my hair cut for free for the first time
in my life have problem with back of my
mouth like a tooth extracted Oliver
hopes this is a temporary hitch that
this will be his first and only time at
stand down Blair Barrett a former naval
electrician feels the same way I do not
want to be homeless I do not like
sleeping outside Barrett struggled to
find work outside of the military and
was laid off from her maintenance job
last year she spent months living in a
shelter while her three-year-old stayed
with family it was just like no job no
money no you know I couldn't pay the
rent and before I got eviction on my
crate I'd rather go to a shelter Barrett
is part of the growing population of
homeless veteran women with children now
she is looking for work in a permanent
home I'm motivated and I want to work I
want to have a normal provide a normal
life for my child and for my family and
I want to succeed but just the times are
not allowed me to do that like Oliver
Barrett is determined to use all the
resources at stand down to get her life
in order my game plan was to just hit
the floor running and try to get as much
help as I could so thank you I had some
issues that I needed to take care of
some legal issues and I also have some
health issues of course the housing
issues I got a massage I made it that I
really want to be stable again and this
is like a great opportunity for me to do
that while services are plentiful at
stand down housing options are not there
is a shortage of shelter spots for the
hundreds of vets looking for housing
this weekend but as much as stand down
is about taking advantage of services
it's also a place for people haunted by
their military experiences to feel whole
again there are many people here they
literally sacrifice put themselves into
harm's way
you put your body or soul your mind on a
line for your country they deserve
something they deserve something they
really do facing demons with the support
of fellow vets is the heart of stand
down and a new generation of vets from
Iraq and Afghanistan is facing similar
challenges Kenneth codes suffered a
traumatic brain injury from a roadside
bomb and he used drugs and alcohol to
cope ultimately it forced him onto the
streets it's a domino effect you start
using all of a sudden I started losing
everything and all of a sudden like and
I pushed everybody away from me to where
nobody wanted to be around me so when I
hit my bottom eye and have no one that I
didn't have no family I don't have
nobody you know what i mean so I that's
how I ended up homeless for 26 year old
coots seeing homeless Vietnam vets
struggle with recovery has been a

for at least a couple of days so they
know it's like to be sober you know what
I mean like it gives him that little bit

yeah I don't know you know I don't know

what it is that is inhibiting them from

oh say can you see by the dawn's early

for some the weekend offered a chance to

dismissed at the homeless court robert

the hardest part is knowing that stand

it's challenging it heartbreaking when
